hi and welcome you listening to the ex
when he to report my name is Dave in
this episode 1472 a n today's date is
January 15th 2018 and thus out of the
episode is all the theories about the
deteriorating economy are now becoming
facts let's get into the economic
collapse financial news now as we can
see the retail industry it's not doing
as well as the core media makes it seem
like it's doing and of course they're
telling us that you know retail is
bouncing back thank god this for this
holiday season the retail apocalypse it
looks like it could be over and this is
something that the retailer's really
needed and then we see that Macy's and
many other stores Neiman Marcus some are
closing stores some are declaring
bankruptcy we see Walmart is eliminating
about a thousand jobs we know that there
all of a sudden they closed you know
something like 260 Sam's Club warehouses
or something like that and it looks like
there's gonna be 11 thousand jobs lost
for Walmart and that is a lot of people
that are going to be out of work now
what's very interesting about all this
is that the corporate media was making a
really big deal about the credit card
spending the debt spending over the
holiday season and this is what they
used to gauge how the holiday season was
doing and they came out with their
numbers and all four point nine percent
or whatever they came out with and they
were trying to convince us that this is
something that looks fantastic everyone
is going out and spending their money
and we realized that you know people's
savings were declining and what were
people really spending their money on
using their credit cards because as we
know it wasn't just for the holiday
season well if we go back a little bit
Joseph Borg director of the Alabama
security Commission he suggested that
people were taking out home equity loans
and cash advances on credit cards to
make Bitcoin purchases now what's very
interesting about this is that it seems
like he turned out to be right and he
looked into this and he saw that it
looks like the speculation which what he
which he was too
thing about is now confirmed because
there was a new survey conducted by Len
DTU which found that among other things
nearly 20% of people who have purchased
Bitcoin have done so using their credit
cards now once again we saw credit card
levels rise at the same time Bitcoin was
going up very very quickly and of course
everyone saw this and they said oh I got
to get into this I want to make some
money off of this now what they saw was
first more than half 51 point seven
eight percent a respondent stated that
they either used a credit or debit card
to fund their account to purchase
Bitcoin specifically thirty three point
six three percent of investors were
using debit cards while eighteen percent
were using credit cards and this was a
factor in having the credit the debit
cards move up to four point nine percent
because when we look at the real sales
and we talked about this before the
actual holiday sales are not that great
this is why stores are closing down this
is why more and more stores are gonna
declare bankruptcy because the actual
sales the actual profits they're just
not there now there was another report
out there and we talked about the
Student Loan debacle here where a lot of
people are taking up student loans they
were promised you know they were gonna
get this great job when they graduated
and we see that this has not come true
at all and what we're seeing is that the
government you know everyone is out
there get a good education once you get
this good education you can go out and
you get this great job and what we're
seeing is a lot of these individuals who
are going for this education they're
living with their parents they can't
find a job they can't pay for their
student loans the student loans have
been modified over time they look at
your income then they modify it over
time so you can make these payments and
the only reason they do these things is
because the system is not working this
is why they have to modify all of this
and what we're seeing right now is the
total student loan debt is around one
point four eight trillion and nearly 50%
more than
all credit card debt in America now we
can see that this number one point four
eight trillion this is going to reach
three point three trillion by 2024 and
what's very interesting is that the
Brookings Institution reports the
following that the student default
crisis is much much worse than we
thought and when they looked into this
they say that nearly 40% of borrowers
may default on their student loans by
2023 a this is a staggering number if
one assumes the DBA sees forecast that
there will be roughly 2.5 trillion in
student loan outstanding by 2020 it
would mean that no less than one
trillion in student loans will be in
some form of a default in two years an
outcome which will necessitate guess
what probably a bailout from the
taxpayers and if we start to look at all
this data that's coming in the student
loans the pension problem we're looking
at the retail crisis we're looking at
the housing crisis all these
institutions all these studies are
starting to show us that these things
that we've been looking at these
different economic sectors well they're
all coming true everything that we
looked into everything that we thought
was going to happen when we saw this
economy deteriorating is actually
happening because they're surveying

what is going on and they're saying the
same exact thing now the real estate
market is falling apart also a lot of
people can't see that yet there are
other people that have been writing in

prices are coming down traffic's drying
up and the realtors they don't know
what's going on in New York City
landlords are suddenly in a position of
having to slash their rental rates to
attract tenants now according to the
latest rental report from Douglas
Elliman median rents in the Big Apple
dropped by 2.7 percent year-over-year in
December
and when we look at this we can see that
this has been declining steadily since
around May of 2017 and it's continually
declining at a very very fast pace we
also see that New York City apartment
sales they have collapsed by 25% in the
fourth quarter and this means that New
Yorkers that are looking to sell their
apartment are also taking a hit as
prices have plummeted by negative 9
point 4 percent and volumes which are
down by negative twenty five point four
percent in the for sale market collapsed
sequentially in the fourth quarter as
potential buyers took a pause amid the
growing uncertainty of the economy and
we see also that resale volumes were
down a staggering twenty six point nine
percent as well so when we start to look
at all of this we're starting to see
that yes all of this is becoming fact
it's no longer sitting there going oh
look what's happening here even though
the corporate media the Fed the
government is telling us something
different we're starting to see all
these numbers we're starting to see the
information come in that all the things
that we've been talking about everything
that we've been seeing it's all coming
true now if we look at the commercial
property index we see there's huge
amount of problems in commercial real
estate
it is highly leveraged right now it's
backed by four point three trillion in
bank loans and this is as of November
2017 much of this debt is held by
smaller banks with less than 50 billion
in assets and it's concentrated in
series in their local markets and these
banks are less able to withstand shocks
to collateral values Boston Fed
president eric rosengren
has been very worried about this the
significant decline in collateral values
of series was one of the root causes of
the financial crisis he said and when we
start to look at this we can see that
there are major major problems now if we
look at the brick-and-mortar retail
space
that is really hurting the index for
strip retail fell by 3% in 2017 and the
index for mall prices dropped by 11%
self-storage formerly a white-hot sector
having surged around a hundred and
eighty percent during the fund right
after the financial crisis had has
turned cold after an onslaught of new
supply and prices are down by two
percent for the year lodging took a 12%
plunge that started in 2015 and never
recovered in 2017 the index rose 2% from
the beaten down levels in 2016
even at its peak in 2015 the index
barely hit its peak before the financial
crisis before dropping again it is now
down about 10 percent from its 2007 peak
and when we start to look at all this
and we start to see these numbers and we
start to hear what's really going on and
see what's really going on we start to
understand that the economy is reeling
right now the economy is not doing what
everyone thinks it is doing it is
ripping itself apart and I'm talking

fakes stock market numbers they can go

oh my god we hit 14,000 points the party

this is gonna go on forever and it

they can do it very very well today all

this is not real people this is not

keeping the illusion alive while

something always breaks and something

without them controlling it that's the

they're afraid people are gonna blame

the stock market the plunge Protection
